instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LCD_PWR_EN: What is LCD_PWR_EN? LCD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip that supplies power to the LCD screen to turn on..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> 0v
threads.message:
Tested on external display and image works OK.

<RESISTOR>R9676</RESISTOR> 100K on pin 1 got 3.3V, on pin 2 got 0V (short to ground when turned on).

<TRANSISTOR>Q9607</TRANSISTOR> pin 2 got 3.3V so in N channel mosfet when G is higher than S (higher than 0V as S is ground) is should be open?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> 0v
threads.message: LCD not recognized. Tried known good LCD assembly? Diode mode on pins 4 6 7 of LCD connector? Could also be a bad GPU, heat it up to about 100C and see if it works again.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> 0v
threads.message:
Solved. There was no connection between J9000 pin 4 and <CAPACITOR>C9010</CAPACITOR>. Jumper and works fine again.
Thank you Duke for tips.
